Tackling the pressures of diet culture this New Year

By Emma McGreevy

Emma McGreevy (she/her) offers her advice for breaking up with diet culture and itâ€™s expectations

Slow Cookers: the student alternative to the air fryer

By Emma McGreevy

Megan Stoker (she/her) and Katy Leverett (she/her) discuss the benefits of slow cookers for students

Guy Fawkes Inn

I arrived at the inn on a Sunday afternoon, having consumed nothing but a cup of coffee since the night before. Naturally I was looking forward to a roast, but much to my dismay they had stopped serving food.

Red Chilli

I have had too many distressing encounters with lukewarm bowls of viscous compost; I am harrowed by apparitions of diced sludge; I have had surfeit of cashew nut. If Red Chilli might have changed my mind, it didn't.

Bruks Cafe

After spending copious amounts of student loan in Topshop, what more could you ask for than a nice cup of tea, a scone and a healthy stint in a calm, quiet cafe? At lunch time I usually opt for the delicious homemade soup (PS3.95), which arrives literally in a matter of milliseconds.

O'Brien's Sandwich Bar

But I decided to go Oirish. I ordered a Shambo with bacon, brie and cranberry. A shambo, I found out, is toasted bread in the shape of a shamrock with herbs - rosemary, I think - baked into the top. It worked well.

Will Heaven's Granny's Kedgeree

My granny is a little bit bonkers. Not in the same way as her husband - who thinks he is a Captain in the navy again - but bonkers nonetheless. While he parades around the house shutting the curtains at midday and ordering the dog to stand up straight, she (aged 80) plays tennis and makes delicious wedding cakes.

L'Antica Locanda

L'Antica Locanda's location in the Shambles makes it the perfect destination for a romantic dinner, even if the prices are a little high. Helen and James are in the thrall of phallic pepper grinders and authentic Italian food.

Homemade Ice Cream

Summer isn't about angst-ridden nights in with Gordon Ramsay... Summer is about getting outside, thinking you're too cool for the sun to burn you, barbeques and The Beach Boys. This recipe will bring together all of these things in one delicious icy dream.

Reeds Cafe and 'Tea Rooms'

The panino was OK - it came quickly and with salad and Doritos, but could have used some chutney. The orange wasn't fizzy so I hurled it back at them and flipped over my table, shouting loudly.

VJ's Art Bar

Food, cocktails and art all merrily hand in hand. The project of two sisters, VJ's is found in one of York's sneaky little corners. It's ideal to escape the hubbub of Parliament Street.

Pivo

I have never been to a Bavarian beerhaus but, if my imagination serves me correctly, each one should have at least one long, knobbly, wooden bar-top carved from the bole of a great hornbeam, several hundred variety lagers flavoured with all manner of implausible fruit and veg and one winsome barmaid who is blonde and pigtailed, and built by the same company that did Munich cathedral.

Kennedy's

As the waiter laid each meal in front of them, one-by-one the three gasped with delight as they realised that the sizes of their meals would more than satisfy their meagre frames!

Recipe: Devilled Kidneys

The devilled kidney was a popular breakfast dish during the Edwardian era among young men who wore white suits and administered Britain's new colonies in the Suez.

Melton's

Caught between a rather small Sainsbury's and a ghostly churchyard, Melton's is an unlikely find. Having been invited out to dinner by a group of London businessmen (they hoped lively female company would shake up their dull corporate lives), we were prepared for a stuffy atmosphere and self-important food.

The Blue Bell

If you like pickled eggs, you'll like The Blue Bell. If you're not fond of pickled eggs, but you like the idea of a pickled egg, then you'll certainly be agreeable to a stint in The Blue Bell.

Harlequin's Cafe

The cafe is upstairs and has the sort of airy feel to it which borders on the bit-too-empty. The staff looked at us suspiciously when we entered; "Muggles?", whispered one young waitress.

Homemade Beef Burger

By James Bithell

Coffee Culture

There was a single lonely window overlooking the street. Bronte fans might speculate that if the Rochesters had moved to town, this would have been 'that room': perfect for the secretion of embarrassing, unwanted lunatic relatives.

Garlic Chilli Chicken

By James Bithell

At the risk of sounding like Jamie Oliver, we students eat a lot of crap. Never would a night out last year have been complete without a chilli burger and chips from Mr Efe on the way home from Toffs or Gallery.

Ha! Ha! Bar & Canteen

Ha! Ha! prides itself on good bistro-type food, but if you go for a drink the chances are you won't leave with fond memories.

Hotel du Vin

This bistro is the best in York with prices to match. So start saving. Give up as many things as you can for lent, because the five stars are no joke. The Hotel has a clear aim: to attract a rich clientele coming to York for the racing season.

The Black Swan

This is a friendly pub. Too friendly. Worryingly friendly. When you walk into the bar, complete strangers will nod and smile in welcome.

Roast Woodcock on Toast

By James Bithell

Wondering what to do with those woodcock you bagged in the shoot at the weekend? Well here's the recipe for you.

Risotto Alli Studenti

Poaching chicken avoids overcooking, reduces sunflower-oil intake and lets you flavour the meat. So cut two chicken breasts in half lengthways and place them in a couple of pints of boiling veg stock for about 20 mins or until cooked.

Nineteen

<strong>Location:</strong> Grape Lane, Swinegate <strong>Average Meal Price:</strong> PS25 In the run-up to Christmas, Will and I decided that dinner at Nineteen would be the way to go when we returned after the holidays.

The Lowther

<strong>Location:</strong> 8 Cumberland Street <strong>Rating:</strong> * * * We have settled on a pair of sofas in the back of the bar. The flood-waters were blocking the front door when we arrived.

Buzz Bar (refurbished)

<strong>Location:</strong> Swinegate <strong>Rating:</strong> * * * * Tokyo, you may not know, is now the world's haute cuisine capital. Its restaurants have 191 Michelin stars between them compared to Paris's 97 and New York's 54.

Pass the chickpeas, please

How would the average student cope without bacon sandwiches, cheese toasties and Efe's pizza? <em>Jenny O'Mahony</em> embarks on a week as a tofu-munching vegan.

Which Love Token?

Normally Nouse abhors a cliche like the public abhors Heather Mills McCartney. However, even we must acknowledge that Valentine's Day is approaching, and you had better buy your lover a present or there will be no sexytime for you. We therefore trekked all the way to Costcutter in search of treats to tempt even the shyest of lovers out of their shell this Wednesday; here is what we found.

Which Cocktail?

Which Tapas?

Are you the sort of person that avoids restaurants to prevent an outbreak of dreaded "meal envy", when you decide that the food you have chosen simply isn't as good as that of your dining companion? Do you feel frustrated living in a society that declares that it is simply not good manners to reach over and help yourself to someone's food as they are eating it?
